newsitem.title: RUSSIA: FOCUS - Foreigners move cautiously on Russia T-bills.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Foreigners move cautiously on Russia T-bills.

text.p: Foreign investors, given broader access to the Russian Treasury bill market for the first time on Wednesday, made a cautious start with bids of about $100 million for three- and six- month paper.
Non-residents were allowed to bid for more than three trillion roubles (about $600 million) worth of bills under the terms of two auctions, held under the new scheme.
A central bank official said non-residents bid 500 billion roubles. The two issues were for a total of 11.50 trillion roubles and bids for both were a combined 16.23 trillion.
Access to the market was widened a week ago but the reasons for the slow start appeared to be technical rather than concern at the relatively low yield on offer.
One reason is that Russian banks are not yet ready for the scheme and another is that potential investors are not fully informed about the details, dealers said.
"Most Russian banks authorised to work in this scheme are not yet ready to provide their clients with comprehensive information," said one.
The central bank allowed non-residents to open special rouble accounts at selected Russian banks from August 15.
They can use funds on these accounts to buy and sell GKO discount Treasury bills and OFZ interest-bearing government bonds at auction and in the secondary market.

There is no limit on the amount which can be repatriated from these accounts but purchases of foreign currency must be made through forward deals or options with a term of at least three months, at rates influenced by the central bank, effectively limiting the dollar yield on T-bills to 19 percent.

The average yield on Wednesday's issue of four trillion roubles of three-month bills was 63.18 percent and the yield on an auction of 7.50 trillion roubles of six-month paper was 74.16 percent, both falling slightly from the last auction a week ago.

"The results of today's auctions are a positive indicator for the Finance Ministry and central bank in that they show domestic investors are still strong. The auctions were held under one banner -- holding or lowering the market yield," said Denis Nechayev of MFK bank.

Yields skyrocketed to more than 200 percent in the run-up to Boris Yeltsin's presidential election victory in July. the government has been keen to lower its borrowing costs and this was one reason for broadening access to foreigners.
However, some analysts have said that foreigners interested in investing in T-bills have already found ways into the market at far higher yields.

Restrictions under the old system have led Russian banks to set up semi-legal "grey" schemes, in which foreign investors lend hard currency to a Russian bank, which invests the money in T-bills, sharing the high domestic return with the foreigner.
In line with its policy of lowering yields, the government did not take up any fresh money in the auctions, just rolling over maturing debt.
Combined proceeds were seven trillion roubles, close to the sum the finance ministry repaid on maturing six-month bills.
Sergei Koshlenko of CS First Boston said the six-month issue attracted particular attention.
"The market will be strong tomorrow. Non-resident demand was good and there is great potential interest in these instruments from non-residents. ($ = 5,305 roubles)
